contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USSCraneDD109.jpg|300px|USS Crane (DD-109)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag|1945}} |Ship name= |Ship namesake=[[William M. Crane]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Union Iron Works]], [[San Francisco]], [[California]] |Ship laid down=7 January 1918 |Ship launched=4 July 1918 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=18 April 1919 to 7 June 1922<br />18 December 1939 to 14 November 1945 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck=19 December 1945 |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Sold, 1 November 1946 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[Wickes class destroyer]] |Ship displacement=1,060 tons |Ship length=314 ft 5 in (95.83 m) |Ship beam=31 ft 9 in (9.68 m) |Ship draft=8 ft 6 in (2.59 m) |Ship propulsion= |Ship speed=35 knots (65 km/h) |Ship range= |Ship complement=100 officers and enlisted |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 x 4" (102 mm), 12 x 21" (533 mm) TT. |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Crane'' (DD-109)''' was a [[Wickes class destroyer|''Wickes''-class]] [[destroyer]] in the [[United States Navy]]. She is named for naval officer [[William M. Crane]]. ''Crane'' was launched 4 July 1918 by [[Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation]], [[Union Iron Works]], [[San Francisco]], [[California]]; sponsored by Mrs. M. McGuire; and commissioned 18 April 1919, [[Lieutenant Commander]] [[W. F. Gresham]] in command. ==Service history== Clearing San Francisco 21 April 1919, ''Crane'' arrived at [[Newport, Rhode Island]], 13 May. She sailed for duty in [[Europe]]an waters 5 June, visiting ports in [[England]] and [[France]] and joining the escort for {{USS|George Washington|1908|2}} carrying President [[Woodrow Wilson]] to the peace conference. Returning to [[New York, New York|New York]] 27 July, ''Crane'' was assigned to the [[U.S. Pacific Fleet|Pacific Fleet]], and arrived at San Francisco 1 September. Here she participated in the [[Naval Review]], during which she was visited by [[Secretary of the Navy]] [[Josephus Daniels]] 4 September. After operations off the coast of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], ''Crane'' was placed in reserve at [[San Diego]] 26 January 1920, participating in occasional maneuvers until decommissioned 7 June 1922, at San Diego. Recommissioned 18 December 1939, ''Crane'' joined the [[Neutrality Patrol]] in the [[Pacific]]. She continued patrols and provided training for Naval Reservists and Armed Guard crews until the outbreak of [[World War II]]. ===World War II=== ''Crane'' remained on the west coast on antisubmarine patrol, local escort duty, training exercises, and screening duty for amphibious exercises until 22 April 1944, when she was assigned to the [[West Coast Sound Training School]]. After the war she departed San Diego 2 October 1945, arrived at [[Philadelphia]] 19 October; was decommissioned 14 November 1945; and sold 1 November 1946. ==See also== *[[List of United States Navy destroyers]] ==References== *{{DANFS|http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/c15/crane.htm}} ==External links== *[http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-c/dd109.htm NHC - Photos] *[http://www.navsource.org/archives/05/109.htm NavSource DD-109] {{Wickes_class_destroyer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crane (Dd-109)}} [[Category:Wickes-class destroyers]] [[Category:World War II destroyers of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in San Francisco, California]] [[Category:1918 ships]]
